SIGMA 28-70mm f/2.8 DG DN | ContemporaryFinding Your Perfect Lens SIGMA’s success is often tied to its unwavering commitment to quality and value. Every SIGMA lens reflects a meticulous design philosophy that prioritizes optical excellence, durability, and usability. Lens features such as advanced coatings, sophisticated lens elements, and superior autofocus capabilities provide unmatched value for photographers seeking reliability coupled with exceptional image quality. SIGMA’s state-of-the-art factory in Aizu, Japan, is the heart of its manufacturing operations. Aside from a small number of processes, almost every aspect of SIGMA lens manufacturing takes place inside this factory. By maintaining production in Japan, SIGMA not only preserves its heritage but also ensures that every lens meets the company’s high standards, solidifying its reputation as a leader in optical innovation. SIGMA lenses are truly ‘Made in Japan.’ With dozens of lenses available for modern cameras, we have compiled a list of SIGMA lenses that best fit for a variety of photography genres. First, it’s important to understand the differences between SIGMA’s Art, Contemporary, and Sports lens lines. Art lenses provide the sharpest, most detailed image quality. Contemporary lenses, while not quite as sharp as Art lenses, provide high quality images in a more compact package. The Sports lenses deliver rugged lenses that provide a fast aperture and autofocus system, ideal for fast moving action. Additionally, SIGMA lenses are marked with one of three designations which point to the type of camera system it can be used with. DC: Designed for APS-C (crop sensor) cameras. DN: Designed for mirrorless cameras (full-frame and APS-C). DG: Designed for full-frame cameras (can also be used on APS-C). To help you find the perfect optic for your needs, this guide is organized by shooting genre, highlighting the top SIGMA lenses for every type of photographer. Great lenses for this genre typically offer exceptional sharpness across the entire frame to render fine details, often feature wider focal lengths to encompass broad vistas, and possess robust weather sealing to withstand unpredictable outdoor conditions. While zoom lenses provide versatility, prime lenses are often favored for their ultimate image quality and wider maximum apertures, which can be beneficial for low-light situations like dawn, dusk, or even astro-landscapes. 1. SIGMA’s success is often tied to its unwavering commitment to quality and value. Every SIGMA lens reflects a meticulous design philosophy that prioritizes optical excellence, durability, and usability. Lens features such as advanced coatings, sophisticated lens elements, and superior autofocus capabilities provide unmatched value for photographers seeking reliability coupled with exceptional image quality.

SIGMA’s state-of-the-art factory in Aizu, Japan, is the heart of its manufacturing operations. Aside from a small number of processes, almost every aspect of SIGMA lens manufacturing takes place inside this factory. By maintaining production in Japan, SIGMA not only preserves its heritage but also ensures that every lens meets the company’s high standards, solidifying its reputation as a leader in optical innovation. SIGMA lenses are truly ‘Made in Japan.’

With dozens of lenses available for modern cameras, we have compiled a list of SIGMA lenses that best fit for a variety of photography genres.

First, it’s important to understand the differences between SIGMA’s Art, Contemporary, and Sports lens lines. Art lenses provide the sharpest, most detailed image quality. Contemporary lenses, while not quite as sharp as Art lenses, provide high quality images in a more compact package. The Sports lenses deliver rugged lenses that provide a fast aperture and autofocus system, ideal for fast moving action.

Additionally, SIGMA lenses are marked with one of three designations which point to the type of camera system it can be used with.

DC: Designed for APS-C (crop sensor) cameras.
DN: Designed for mirrorless cameras (full-frame and APS-C).
DG: Designed for full-frame cameras (can also be used on APS-C).

To help you find the perfect optic for your needs, this guide is organized by shooting genre, highlighting the top SIGMA lenses for every type of photographer.

Landscape Photography: Capturing the Beauty of the Great Outdoors

Landscape photography is the art of capturing the world around us, from sweeping mountain ranges to serene coastal scenes. Great lenses for this genre typically offer exceptional sharpness across the entire frame to render fine details, often feature wider focal lengths to encompass broad vistas, and possess robust weather sealing to withstand unpredictable outdoor conditions. While zoom lenses provide versatility, prime lenses are often favored for their ultimate image quality and wider maximum apertures, which can be beneficial for low-light situations like dawn, dusk, or even astro-landscapes.

Astrophotography: Capturing the Cosmos

Astrophotography is a demanding yet rewarding genre focused on capturing the beauty of the night sky. Astrophotographer’s main challenge is gathering faint light from distant stars and galaxies, which requires lenses with very wide maximum apertures (like f/1.4 or f/1.8) to keep ISO levels low and avoid noise. A wide-angle focal length is essential for capturing expansive subjects like the Milky Way, while superior optical quality is needed to render stars as sharp pinpoints of light from corner to corner, free of aberrations like sagittal coma flare.

It boasts exceptional control over optical aberrations, ensuring stars remain pinpoint-sharp across the entire frame. Wildlife Photography: Capturing the Untamed World

Wildlife photography is a thrilling pursuit that requires patience, skill, and the right equipment to capture animals in their natural habitat. The ideal lenses for this genre provide significant telephoto reach to photograph subjects from a safe and respectful distance. Critically, they must have fast, responsive, and quiet autofocus systems to track moving animals, along with effective optical stabilization (OS) to ensure sharp images when shooting handheld. A durable, weather-sealed construction is also essential for enduring the demanding conditions of the outdoors.

  • Why It’s Great for Wildlife: This lens is a marvel of optical engineering, delivering 500mm of super-telephoto reach in a stunningly compact and lightweight body.
